description: From Ancient Greek ἐμφατικός (emphatikós, “emphatic”), from ἐμφαίνω (emphaínō, “I show, present”), from ἐν (en, “in”) + φαίνω (phaínō, “I shine, show”); related to ἔμφασις (émphasis) and English emphasis.

adjectives.description: emphatic (comparative more emphatic, superlative most emphatic)

examples: He gave me an emphatic no when I asked him out.

entries.meaning: (grammar) Belonging to a set of English tense forms comprising the auxiliary verb do + an infinitive without to.

definitionGroups.group: (phonology) Belonging to a series of obstruent consonants in several Afro-Asiatic languages that are distinguished by a guttural (co-)articulation.

entries.meaning: pharyngealized consonants in Arabic, Hebrew, other Northwest Semitic languages, and Berber languages
ejective consonants in Ge'ez, Amharic, other Ethiopic Semitic languages, Chadic and Cushitic languages
(phonology, archaic except in layman’s use) Referring to the above consonants as well as /ħ/ and /ʕ/ (these being seen as emphatic equivalents of /h/ and /ʔ/).
(linguistics) A word or phrase adding emphasis, such as "a lot" or "really".
